author: Philip J. Fry II

text:
LOVE IT.

To overuse a cliche, this gave me chills when I first walked into the castle, because I wasn't expecting THAT after most of the rest of the soundtrack didn't impress me as much.  Shanoa was easily my favorite lead of the DS era, and despite being an intentionally flat character, might even be my favorite lead in the series.  Yes, even next to the whippers and Alucard.  

She also remained fun to play in Harmony of Despair, even though that game ultimately became "grind as Soma forever for drops, or grind as Jonathan forever to actually get damage."

author: D.E. McKnight

text: As a person who has not played a Castlevania game, i am wondering which game would you recommend for someone new to the series.  I have played some metroidvanias in the past ie Guacamelee, but I am just not sure about what would be a good entry to start with.  Speaking of metroidvanias, I also miss the great music of Michiru Yamane.
author: Eric C.

text: Symphony of the Night is arguably the best Metroidvania, and Super Castlevania IV is the best non-Metroidvania. They're two of the easiest entries in the series, too, so they should be really good for a beginner.
author: drunyon214

text: Eric C. Symphony of the Night.
author: jb1980ist

text: I think Symphony of the Night is one of the worst Metroidvanias in the series. Overall, the better games are Aria of Sorrow and the DS trilogy, in no particular order.
author: Nuclehon

text:
I've only played Dawn of Sorrow and the original Castlevania for the NES and I really liked both.
Though I can really only recommend Dawn of Sorrow to a "casual" player. The original Castlevania is fairly brutal in its game design; most notably how you can't change your jumps once you've started them.

Interestingly, I'd categorize the original Castlevania as a strategy platformer. The entire gameplay is fairly slow and methodical, and there are some interesting choices you can make about how to clear stages.
author: Beremor

text: If you haven't, I recommend trying some of the alternative modes for the DS Castlevania games (I.E., Julius mode for Aria/Dawn of Sorrow and/or Hard Max Lv. 1 for a variety of the games). At the very least, the latter gave me an entirely new appreciation for Order of Ecclesia's bosses, and I suspect if I were to try the mode on some of the earlier DS CV games I'd feel similarly.
author: D.E. McKnight

author: plhearn

text:
Symphony of the night is by far the best Metroidvania-styled Castlevania game. It is also the first :)

Anyway, don't make the mistake and accept the first ending you encounter. Almost every castlvania game since SotN has a bad ending at the half-way point.. and it is really easy to miss the part that let's you get past that.
author: MeSako

text: Guacamelee is awesome, no CV will ever surpass it IMO.  But if you want to Super Castlevania IV on the platform side.... and pretty much all the DS CV games;but really Guacamelee is the best.
author: Magnum Crackoff

text: The GBA Castlevanias are pretty good, too (I advise you play Aria of Sorrow before Dawn of Sorrow as the latter is a direct sequel to the former; and Aria has a mind-blowing twist.
author: EvilMariobot

text: As a person who has not played a Castlevania game, i am wondering which game would you recommend for someone new to the series.  I have played some metroidvanias in the past ie Guacamelee, but I am just not sure about what would be a good entry to start with.  Speaking of metoridvanias, I also miss the great music of Michiru Yamane.
author: Eric C.

text:
Eric C. Symphony of the Night is what codified Metroidvania (with Super Metroid, of course). It is an excellent game and easy to find (it's on PSN). It's easy, though, but it's the first one, so it's fine. I personally like Aria of Sorrow, as it was may first Castlevania. The DS Castlevania games are all good, IMO. Portrait of Ruin gets a special shout out for its depth of content.

Of the classic games, Castlevania 1, 3, Super, Bloodlines, and Rondo of Blood are all excellent. 2 is infamously strange, but worth checking out too. Super might be the easiest one to get into, while Rondo of Blood is arguably the best one. You can get Super for the SNES (and virtual console), while you can get the Rondo of Blood remake (with an unlock able original) on the PSP.
author: Jonathan Hodrick

text: Eric C. Sorry for the long post! Go with Symphony of the Night for Metroidvania and Super Castlevania for classic.
author: Jonathan Hodrick

text: first
author: Eren plays guitar

text: It's been almost 10 years since we last got to play a new Metroidvania from Igarashi. I wasn't the biggest fan of Ecclesia in comparison to his other games as I found the difficulty balance lacking and the disconnected worlds to be disappointing, but it was still a very good entry. It's crazy how Bloodstained will only release in 2018, but Igharashi knows he has additional pressure with Kickstarter behind it and I'm all for a carefully crafted game that doesn't feel rushed or blandly trying to pull nostalgia strings... looking at you, Mighty No. 9.
author: SupraDarky

text:
I always wanted the Metroid-style Castlevanias to have a section outside the castle that connects to it. DoS gave me one town and I was glad, then PoR had the portraits which made me feel hopeful that there would be more like that, and Order of Ecclesia actually had areas outside the castle... but completely unrelated to each other and really short. Let's see if Bloodstained gives it to us.
Also, best song in the game by far. By that point you feel so excited to go back into Castlevania and you're received by this song.
author: Alfonso ST

text:
I always wanted the Metroid-style Castlevanias to have a section outside the castle that connects to it. text: MIghty No. 9 ohhhh boy... I'm pretty sure everyone's feelings resonate together about that monster. Anyways as a newbie to the Castlevania franchise I'm actually pretty excited to see Bloodstained come out. Only playing Aria of Sorrow, I'm  looking forward to seeing similar elements brought back. As for Ecclesia, I fell in love with the music...I'm looking at the cinematic intro and An Empty Tome of course. So I'll definitely play it eventually...XD

text: You thought OoE's balance was lacking? It was great, the previous few Metroidvanias were super easy and this one finally gave us some actual difficulty making it one of my favorite Metroidvanias. Plus, the Castlevania 2 reference near the end was flawless.
